Two Types of a Book

  • â€œIn a book, as in all things, there are lines of articulation or segmentarity, strata and territories; but also lines of flight, movements of deterritorialization and destratification.â€ (p. 3) 1
  • â€œAs an assemblage, a book has only itself, in connection with other assemblages and in relation to other bodies without organs (CsO, BwO)â€ (p. 4)
  • Two types of book:
  1. root-book. $1, 2, 4, …$
  2. radicle-system. Joyce, Nietzsche2. from $n$ to $n-1$

Radicle-System

  1. & 2. Principles of connection and heterogeneity: any point of a rhizome can be connected to anything other, and must be.
  2. Principle of multiplicity: it is only when the multiple is effectively treated as a substantive, â€œmultiplicity,â€ that it ceases to have any relation to the One as subject or object, natural or spiritual reality, image and world.
  3. Principle of asignifying rupture: against the oversignifying breaks separating structures or cutting across a single structure.
  4. & 6. Principle of cartography and decalcomania: a rhizome is not amenable to any structural or generative model.
  • â€œThought is not arborescent, and the brain is not a rooted or ramified matter.â€ (p. 15)

The East 3 presents a different figure: a relation to the steppe and the garden (or in some cases, the desert and the oasis), rather than forest and field.â€ (p.18)

There are knots (cf. levinas) of arborescence in rhizomes, and rhizomatic offshoots in roots.â€ (p. 20)
  • RHIZOMATICS = SCHIZOANALYSIS = STRATOANALYSIS = PRAGMATICS = MICROPOLITICS = POP ANALYSIS (pp. 22, 24)
  • A plateau is always in the middle, not at the beginning or the end. A rhizome is made of plateaus. A rhizome has also no beginning or end; it is always in the middle, between things, interbeing, intermezzo. (pp. 21, 25)
